PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the government's part backdown on the pensioner shares issue in the face of the protest of thousands of Australia's senior citizens. Do the minister and his government not understand that the government's latest policy position will still discourage the elderly from investing in shares? How can that be in the interest of pensioners, or in the national interest, when national savings are so low?

—When one looks at the claims that have been made over the course of the last year as to the profound effect on sales of shares that the government's decision would have, one has to say that those profound effects simply did not occur. The number of people who were supposed to sell simply did not. It does not mean that some did not, but the extraordinary claims that people in here were making as to the rate of the sell-off were never attained.

PARA.TAB: What it now means is that pensioners will be able to look at a whole range of investments, including the buying of shares, which will be treated in exactly the same way. The government has always been of the view that that is equitable. There has always been a problem in being able to invest in the kind of investment that has shares as part of a portfolio and have it treated in one way and then having an opportunity to buy shares directly and have them treated differently. What the decision last year sought to do was to make the treatment of shares consistent in every respect. It did, in fact, achieve that.

As a result of the representations that have been made to the government—and they were made, as I said yesterday, by many people in the caucus who expressed their views on it, not simply this week but over the course of time—the government made the announcement last night that shares acquired before 18 August 1992 will now be exempted from the measure. I think that that decision more than adequately addresses the concerns of those in the caucus that have been expressed over the last 12 months. As far as the government is concerned, the matter rests there.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a stupid idea of a stupid government.
—If it was such a stupid idea, why did Senator Ian Macdonald put his hand up for it—along with every single one of his colleagues?

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I might press the minister a little further after that somewhat confusing answer. Is it not in the national interest and in the interest of pensioners that they be encouraged to be more self-reliant and to save? Why does the minister not go the whole way and admit that the policy was an error and abolish it altogether?

—There are assets and income tests for pensioners. They were placed there to make sure that we had equitable treatment across the board for pensioners—so that at any one point in time they were treated equitably across the board. The decision that the government announced last night makes that treatment even more equitable than it had been in the past.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and relates to bi-cultural counselling for torture and trauma survivors from the Bosnian conflict. I refer the minister to an agreement between the Commonwealth and the New South Wales governments to provide funding for bi-cultural counselling. Are other states also entering these agreements?

—Senator West raises the issue of Australia assuming a responsibility to assist with the human tragedy of what was formerly Yugoslavia. In doing so, by the end of this financial year we will have approved some 8,000 people from former Yugoslavia coming to Australia under a special humanitarian program. We have been able to do that with the support not only of all sides of this parliament but also the broader community, particularly the community that represents the interests of those people from former Yugoslavia.

PARA.TAB: We have also recognised that once people are in Australia there is a need for culturally sensitive torture and trauma counselling. We do this not just for people from former Yugoslavia but for refugees from whatever part of the world they come. In this particular instance we can see almost nightly the sorts of devastating experiences that the ongoing conflict in former Yugoslavia is presenting and the particular need of those who come to this country resulting from those experiences.

As a consequence, at a meeting in June this year with the state and federal ministers for immigration and ethnic affairs, I reached an agreement with the New South Wales minister, Mr Photios, to provide additional funding on a matching grant basis to assist the New South Wales service for the treatment and rehabilitation of torture and trauma survivors, STARTTS. The aim of the offer was to provide bi-cultural counselling for victims of torture and trauma from the Bosnian region in particular.

The offer was also available to Victoria. The parliamentary secretary to the Premier, Mr Honeywood, indicated at that meeting that Victoria would be interested in taking it up. As a consequence, the offer on the table from the federal government was that both STARTTS and the Victorian equivalent—the Victorian Foundation for the Survivors of Torture Incorporated—should, on receipt of a detailed application, receive a one-year special grant of up to $35,000 each to assist survivors of torture and trauma from the Bosnian region of former Yugoslavia. That comes on top of other funding we make available—some $400,000 to the national torture and trauma network, under grant in aid and migrant access project schemes, as well as some $900,000 to the 19 grants in aid that are provided for community based organisations to assist those who come from former Yugoslavia. We recognise the acute need of those from the Bosnian region; as a consequence that offer was on the table.

As I said, New South Wales has indicated that it is ready to provide the additional service. However, I am disappointed that some two months after the ministerial meeting, despite the interest of his parliamentary secretary, the Victorian Premier, Mr Kennett, has still to agree to provide a matching grant to this most deserving service. I find it very hard to understand Mr Kennett's difficulty in taking up this particular offer. My officers tell me that, reportedly, he feels that since the states do not decide who is allowed to settle permanently in the states—in this case the state of Victoria—the Victorian government should not be responsible for meeting the settlement costs that follow. I find this quite a stunning response, particularly when we take into account the fact that the amount of money we are talking about is much less than the cost of the reintroduction of silver service in the Victorian parliament.
I appeal to Mr Kennett to make a decision, to make it quickly and to make it in the interests of those people who have had to suffer much before arriving in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the government still standing by the central plank of its industrial relations reform agenda to allow non-unionised employees to engage in enterprise bargaining without union involvement?

—One thing we will not do is allow the opposition to define for us the central plank of our industrial relations policy. We have made our position very clear, as did the Prime Minister to the ACTU this week. The Minister for Industrial Relations is to report at the ACTU congress today that the government—to quote the Prime Minister—`wants to see enterprise agreements extended to the non-union sector, but we won't see it done in ways which allow for reduced wages and conditions'. That remains the case, and it has been reiterated by Mr Brereton to the ACTU this morning. Those opposite who are enthusiastically waiting for us to institute a change that will allow wage cutting and the slashing of working conditions of Australian workers will have to wait a long time.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I have a copy of Mr Brereton's speech and it certainly does not address the issues that Senator McMullan just mentioned. In view of the fact that the minister has not answered the question, does this represent another pathetic cave-in and payback by the government in the face of electoral blackmail by the union movement as enunciated by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Tickner, at the ACTU conference yesterday?
—No.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the Minister's announcement last April concerning the commencement of a review of legislation regulating Australia's international shipping service. Can the minister advise of progress being made in that review, and in particular the level of interest generated in the shipping community?

—The review of part X of the Trade Practices Act is a very important aspect of the government's maritime reform agenda, which is aimed at continuing to improve Australia's international competitiveness. It is of vital concern to both the shipping industry and Australian shippers, as the trade papers testify.

PARA.TAB: I might add on the question of trade papers that it was of some interest to me to see launched in Australia for the first time on Monday the publication Lloyd's List. Lloyd's List is the oldest continuing English speaking newspaper in the world. It was launched in 1734 in Lloyd's coffee house in London.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's very interesting.

—Indeed, and I know that it is on Senator Boswell's reading list. It is of some note to see that this very old English language newspaper released its first Australian publication on Monday and contained an editorial on the part X review.

PARA.TAB: The review is being conducted by a three-member panel compromising the chairman, Mr Pat Brazil, Professor Ted Kolsen and Captain John Evans. These people were selected because of their complementary skills and top level expertise in the areas of law, transport economics and shipping management, but not as representatives of any particular sectional interests. Their task is to conduct a comprehensive and independent assessment of the complex issues arising from the review's wide-ranging terms of reference. These include examining the scope and justification of exemptions currently available under part X to shipping conferences and the appropriate degree of regulation of Australia's inward liner cargo services.

I recently met with the members of the panel to mark the midpoint in their review. I am pleased to advise the Senate that the review is making very good progress. This has been confirmed to me by both shipping and shipper interests.

The panel has been successful in encouraging participation in the review process by exporters, importers, conference and non-conference shipping companies, maritime unions, stevedores, regulatory bodies and government departments. An issues paper was published in late May to assist interested parties in making submissions. In response, over 40 written submissions have been received. The panel members are now conducting interviews with the people who have put in written submissions.

Australia is not the only country to have legislation similar to that in part X and an appreciation of overseas experience also is an important part of the review. I have encouraged the review panel not to compromise the thoroughness of its report by feeling obliged to strictly comply with the six months time frame originally envisaged for the review. Whilst this is likely to put back slightly the 31 October reporting date to later this year, it reflects the degree of participation there has been in the review by the shipping community and its vital interest in its outcome. I urge anyone with an interest in Australia's international shipping services to make his views known as soon as possible to the review secretariat, if he has not already done so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The minister would be aware that the Starcke wilderness, a magnificent area of rainforest, mangroves and coastal wetlands on the Cape York Peninsula, has been advertised for sale in the Wall Street Journal by its present owner George Quaid. I understand the Premier of Queensland has publicly urged the Commonwealth government to block the overseas sale of Starcke. Does the Treasurer share the view that the foreign acquisition of Starcke wilderness would further the national interest?
—That is not a matter about which I have had any briefing at all, so I will refer it to the Treasurer and get a reply.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would expect the Minister representing the Treasurer to know something about foreign investment policy and the Foreign Investment Review Board. So I ask the minister: does he not think that it is an inevitable and very visible consequence of a totally laissez faire approach to foreign investment policy under his government, in the last decade, that we should stand to lose such a national asset?

—There is not a totally laissez faire attitude to foreign investment by this government. There has been a significant reduction in the amount of regulation. It is not as much as those people opposite would wish but is more than Senator Kernot would wish. The government is trying to strike a reasonable balance. As to whether this is a logical outcome—
—You are not game to say anything. Why don't you have an opinion on it?

—When I was a kid they used to make us write out those handwriting exercises about empty vessels making the most sound. Does everyone remember that? I never knew it was so accurate, until now. The foreign investment policy does give us the capacity to take environmental issues into account. I assume that is part of what the Treasurer will be wishing to do. I will refer the question to him and get an answer.

—I direct my question to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. On several occasions, the minister has responded to questions about government support for the arts and its contribution to particular successes, such as the Piano and, of course, the important performing arts touring program Playing Australia. There is also important private sector support for the arts and cultural activities. Can the minister advise the Senate of the nature of such support?

—The question of the partnerships between various levels of government and between those levels and the private sector is a very important part of establishing a sufficient financial base for a strong arts and cultural industry. Therefore, we acknowledge and welcome the fact that there is substantial private sector support for the arts in Australia and that it is, and remains, very important.

PARA.TAB: The statistics that are available do not make it possible to be precise about the absolute dollar value of private sector support. However, corporate sector sponsorship of the arts in 1992, excluding film production and heritage activity, has been estimated at about $57 million, with an additional $3.1 million being spent on the acquisition of art works. Of course, there is private sector support in areas like investment in film and television, bequests and loans to public galleries.

TALK.START.PARA: —You said all this yesterday.
—Actually I did not, but Senator Herron is welcome to listen. I gave another very good answer yesterday about something quite different.
—You gave the same thing yesterday.

—Yesterday we did not have an arts question, but just relax Senator Herron and go back and read the Hansard. There are important things done here and fortunately a lot of Australians recognise that this is a very important industry that creates a lot of jobs for Australians, and I realise that they are not jobs that have the stamp of approval of the opposition, but they are still jobs that employ 220,000 Australians and I intend to speak up for them, however much the opposition complains.

PARA.TAB: One of the significant things we need to look at which is a cause of some concern and which policy makers—private and public—need to consider is that of the $57 million corporate sector sponsorship, nearly $15 million went to music, but less than $1 million went to literature. That is important for us to consider in terms of the development of the partnership between ourselves and the private sector. There are various ways we can respond to that. We do not have a particular policy intention at the moment, but I think it is a very important issue to flag. It does have consequences for the distribution of funding to the arts in Australia because if it were solely private sector driven, we would get a substantial redistribution towards some art forms and away from others.

Some companies in Australia have taken outstanding initiatives. I recently had the opportunity to relaunch the Australian Art Foundation for Moet and Chandon, which has been very supportive in the visual arts. It has extended it in time and broadened its scope in a way which I greatly welcome. This sort of private sector support for the arts is encouraged by the government through tax deductibility, through the Film Finance Corporation and through indemnity schemes, et cetera. As a result of this budget and two more of the election promises which we kept, we will be introducing legislation to provide tax deductibility for major donations, for bequests to galleries, museums and libraries and for private owners of heritage listed buildings.

I welcome the fact that so many Australian companies are combining their sense of social responsibility with the intelligent pursuit of their self-interest by their support for the arts. I am delighted by the fact that at least government senators continue to support this. I thank Senator Reynolds for raising it and for exposing the inadequacies of the opposition once again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I welcome the minister's statement, particularly—
—It was a statement.

—His response. I welcome the minister's statement in his answer relating to social responsibility. I ask a supplementary question regarding the social responsibility of Qantas to show a higher percentage of Australian films than it does currently. Currently it simply takes those on the general international circuit. With regard to social responsibility, is it not reasonable that Qantas should show a higher percentage of Australian films?
—Could they show Labor in Power?

—It will be a very long time before they get a chance to show `Liberals in Power'. Qantas is free to make any commercial decision it chooses, of course, but I understand the social responsibility point raised by Senator Reynolds. Nobody in the government is likely to issue a directive to Qantas about what sorts of films it should show, but I think its corporate affairs area will undoubtedly be sensitive to the sorts of issues Senator Reynolds has just raised, and I think it should be.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, and concerns another very important Australian industry. Can the minister confirm reports that the government is prepared to back down from its budget decision to impose a massive increase in wholesale sales tax on wine sold at the cellar door?

—I have had some very interesting representations from other parts of the liquor industry congratulating us for doing something to redress the imbalance in tax between wine, spirits and beer and complaining that we did not go far enough because we have still left the tax system massively skewed in favour of the wine industry when compared with other sources of alcohol.

PARA.TAB: I have also seen some very interesting figures recently. A large amount of understandable passion has been generated here about the decline in the consumption of wine since 1986. As I recall, the figure is alleged to be 14 per cent. However, what has not been cited is that the overall consumption of alcohol in Australia has gone down by 14 1/2 per cent in that time. Perhaps this is due to the switch towards low alcohol formulation. It is hard to see the correlation between the decline in consumption of wine and any increase in sales tax. The correlation does not seem to be established.

The logic that one can extrapolate from and say that those will be the consequences for the wine industry is hard to establish. Even Senator Short—because he is a little more economically literate than some, although perhaps not as much as he wishes—was acknowledging yesterday that one of the impacts of the changes in tax on wine would be a substitution effect rather than a reduction. The logic of that position is that if there is a substitution effect there will be offsetting increases elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you were conceding that there would be job losses.
—Therefore, the likely outcome on the jobs will be nil, which is what I have said in the past.
—But you have conceded that there will be job losses.

—There will be nil. There is never a situation where everybody stays in exactly the same job any day in the history of any country in the world. Senator Alston probably does not know that, but most people do. I have seen speculation in newspapers about proposals to change the wine tax, but that is not something I intend to make an announcement about here.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer the minister to recent media reports about the Uruguay Round negotiations. What is the timetable for the completion of the Uruguay Round of multilateral trade negotiations? Are the talks likely to meet the deadline? Is there a sense of growing ambivalence in Europe about the Blair House accord and what does this mean for Australia? How does the government intend to keep industry informed of developments as this important negotiation is brought to a conclusion?

—I thank Senator Jones for his question. The Uruguay Round started in Punta del Este in Uruguay in 1986, and one hopes that it can be concluded this year. Certainly the new director-general of GATT, Peter Sutherland, has put down a timetable in which it is aimed to complete the negotiations for the round by 15 December, the date on which the approval by US Congress for continuing negotiating authority for the United States expires.

PARA.TAB: Australia strongly supports the actions of the director-general. We believe the round can be concluded within the timetable. We have made suggestions to the GATT as to how the next few months can be worked out so that the round will be completed, and many of our suggestions have been taken on by the director-general and applied. The most significant one is that on 15 October there will be a stocktake review of progress in the round and then preparation for resolving the still remaining outstanding points.

The Uruguay Round has been going for seven years, as I have said. A successful outcome for the Uruguay Round to the world economy would mean a boost in income of $200 billion a year and for the Australian economy it would mean an income boost of $2.5 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—They are the calculated figures of a full implementation of a successful outcome of the Uruguay Round in extra income for this country. Because of that, it is one of the most important multilateral trade negotiations in which we have been engaged.

PARA.TAB: I am asked whether the round will conclude in time. As I have said, I believe that it can. All countries in the world that are seeking to see that type of economic stimulus in the global economy are bending their efforts towards that approach.

In order for Australia to best achieve an outcome on agricultural issues in the round, as Chairman of the Cairns Group of free trading agricultural countries, I convened a meeting of the Cairns Group for Geneva on 16, 17 and 18 October. The Cairns Group will at that time consider our tactics so that we can see that the round is successfully concluded.

I am asked by Senator Jones whether there is growing ambivalence in Europe about the Blair House accord. At the end of 1991 Arthur Dunkel, then director-general of GATT, brought down a draft final act which at that point ought to have concluded the round. Australia would have accepted the draft final act. But as a result of ongoing disputes between the United States and Europe an accord was reached at Blair House in Pennsylvania Avenue, Washington, now known as the Blair House accord, which further compromised the agricultural outcome for the draft final act.

We believe that there can be absolutely no compromise beyond the Blair House accord, and since it is an agreement between the European Commission and the United States we believe that there is an obligation on the Europeans to accept their side of that agreement. It would be outrageous if anyone in Europe or elsewhere were to talk about watering down the Blair House accord any further.

Lastly, I am asked how we will consult with Australian industry. We have been doing so sectorally over the last week and will keep industry briefed in the next three and a half months as we complete the negotiations. On 24 November we will be holding the National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference. Arthur Dunkel, the outgoing director-general of GATT, will be a feature speaker at that conference. It will be an opportunity for Australians interested in trade matters to hear the latest update on events.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Why has she deliberately refused to join me in condemning the Treasurer for yesterday's outrageous display of sexism?

—I did not know that Senator Patterson had issued that invitation to me; I had not heard until now that Senator Patterson had that view. I arrived back in my office late last night to hear of this comment for the first time that day, so it was too late to make any comment. I think the best I can say is that there is no doubt that many people say in this place, and the other, words that they would like to bite back or haul back as quickly as possible. I would suspect that these comments by my colleague in the other place—which I think are, in short, somewhat patronising and sexist—are just those sorts of words for Mr Dawkins.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. How can the minister have the audacity to criticise the media for portraying women inappropriately, or the judiciary for being out of step with community attitudes, or business for not doing enough to eliminate sexual harassment, when Mr Dawkins has displayed a completely patronising and sexist attitude to a female parliamentarian? When is the minister going to get round to outrightly condemning him—rather than making the wishy-washy statement that she has just made here in the chamber?

—The honourable senator should know that there is a distinct difference between government policy and how one might deal with policy, between my view about the government initiatives for women and how I might speak to my colleagues. I do not have any confusion about the two.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business and minister representing the minister for the environment. Does the minister accept that the price differential between leaded and unleaded petrol introduced in the budget will not of itself be sufficient to stop leaded petrol being used? Secondly, is it not a fact that, even if all the cars that can use unleaded petrol were to make the shift as a consequence of this price differential, then some 20 to 25 per cent of cars on the road would still be using leaded petrol? Thirdly, is the government aware of the success of the use of ethanol as an octane enhancer and a substitute for lead, and what assistance will the government give to expand this indigenous source of a renewable energy?

—Obviously, though there is a differential between leaded and unleaded petrol, which will be an encouragement for people to use cars that use only unleaded petrol as time goes by, no-one can state categorically that it will eliminate all cars that use leaded petrol. The government has never said that.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, there will be some market pressure to encourage people to shift from cars using leaded petrol to ones using unleaded petrol. Senator Coulter said in his question that 20 to 25 per cent of the cars on the road would still be using leaded petrol; I do not know whether that means immediately or whether he is talking about in a few years time. I will certainly try to get some more information about the projections for the percentages of cars using leaded petrol over, say, the rest of this decade. On Senator Coulter's last question about the use of ethanol as an octane enhancer, I have to admit that I have no details with me. I have no recollection of being briefed about ethanol as an octane enhancer. But I can assure the honourable senator that I will get the information and get it back to him next week.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the budget increase in diesel fuel excise of 5c a litre and the 10 per cent increase in wholesale sales tax, which have been calculated by the road transport industry to add $6,000 and $4,000 respectively in costs for the average owner-operator of a semitrailer or prime mover. This $10,000 increase in the cost of freight will add around $3 to the average trolley load of groceries throughout Australia. This rise will be 25 per cent higher in Western Australia and the Northern Territory, a point that should not escape the Green senators when they come to vote. Was the minister consulted and did he agree to this rise in costs that will so badly affect his constituents?

—Senator Boswell knows perfectly well that what is discussed in cabinet is not canvassed in this chamber. In terms of the first part of Senator Boswell's question, the impact of the excise increases will vary from region to region, as he has quite correctly said. So to that extent the average figures that are provided will not apply exactly; it will depend upon what region one is in.

PARA.TAB: A lot of work has been done over the last few years on freight cost increases in the various regions because of the original recommendations that were made by the Inter-State Commission in respect of vehicle registration charges. I am sure Senator Boswell will remember that exercise. The Inter-State Commission found, I think correctly, that there was a significant oversupply of freight capacity in the road transport industry, principally because of the relatively low capital cost of getting into that industry, and attempted to redress that situation by providing fairly high levels of vehicle registration charges.

I have not had time to do any precise calculation region to region because it is quite a complicated job. But, from my own examination of that original research work, I would estimate that the increase in freight costs as a result of the full cost of the excise increases would be in the order of 2.5 per cent. On average, across Australia freight comprises about 5 per cent of the total cost of goods on the shelf. So the eventual impact will be 2.5 per cent of 5 per cent. The Treasury estimate is that as a result of the budget measures there will be, in the first instance, an increase in the CPI of about 0.2 per cent and then finally of about 0.5 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I am sure that this question will be of interest to many honourable senators, particularly those who have been on the other side for such a long time. Did the minister see an article in the Australian yesterday referring to CSIRO scientists working on rejuvenating cells and the impact this may have on slowing the ageing process? Is the minister able to provide the Senate with any information on this important research?

—I rise to my feet with a youthful spring. Yes, I am aware of the reports about the development of a process, as the result of collaboration between CSIRO and a company called Peptide Technology, that may slow the ageing process in human cells. A substance known as carnosine is present at high levels in human tissues, particularly muscle and brain, but its function is unknown. However, I am advised that CSIRO has found that when human cell cultures are grown in the presence of enhanced levels of carnosine the life is increased by as much as 15 per cent. I think all of us in this place at times, particularly after a long sitting of the chamber, may feel that any substance that would give us a 15 per cent increase in our energy and youth would be more than welcome.
—How do you spell it?

—Mr President, we will put you at the top of the list; all other senators can apply to my office and I will direct them to CSIRO and Peptide. It has been found that the addition of carnosine to age cells culture rejuvenates them in terms of their growth rate and final life span.

PARA.TAB: As I said, the function of carnosine is largely unknown. However, it appears it prevents what is known as crosslinking of proteins to sugars. It is this crosslinking which is implicated in many ageing process, including skin wrinkling, hardening of the arteries and other degenerative diseases. This research not only has implications for the treatment of age-related illnesses but important commercial applications for companies like those involved in the cosmetic industry.

I understand that since this has become known international cosmetic companies have already shown interest in taking up the technology. This is just another example of Australia's excellent intellectual capacity to develop new ideas and new inventions. The big test for Australia has always been to get a successful commercial outcome so that the economic benefits stay in Australia. In this case I am pleased that CSIRO has a good commercial collaboration with Peptide Technology. I believe that we will be able to ensure that if this becomes a commercially successful product the benefits will stay in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. The minister will be aware that during the Prime Minister's recent visit to New Zealand both the Australian and New Zealand governments restated their commitment to ending the union to union trans-Tasman shipping accord. As the Australian government's only bona fide on this issue is a reference to the availability of action under section 45D of the Trade Practices Act to an aggrieved party, what bona fides does Australia really have on this issue when this government is committed to repealing that section? If there are no others, what action does this government intend taking to ensure that traders on both sides of the Tasman have access to the cheapest possible shipping?

—The trans-Tasman shipping accord is an accord between maritime unions on both sides of the Tasman. It has no government support. We do not support it; we have said that any number of times. If any parties feel aggrieved by the existence of that accord, they are at liberty to take action as they would in any normal event.

PARA.TAB: There has been reference to sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act. That certainly is a section where restraint of trade actions can be taken if boycotts or secondary boycotts occur. But if that section of the Trade Practices Act were repealed, a very impressive school of thought believes that actions under the common law dealing with infringement of rights and boycotts of this type would be facilitated.

Indeed, sections 45D and E are fairly poor transcriptions of what existed as civil law remedies anyway. The entrancement that members opposite have about that section of the Trade Practices Act is an entrancement because they invented it. Whether it works efficiently is another matter and, as I say, an impressive body of legal opinion has it that it does not work all that effectively and that the civil law would be a better remedy.

The notoriety of that particular avenue does not mean to say there would be no remedies. It that avenue were repealed and industrial relations taken out of the Trade Practices Act, as this government believes they should be, it would not mean that if restraint of trade actions were being taken which involved industrial actions, there would not be legal remedies. There would be. Because of that, the government feels able to say that we do not support the trans-Tasman accord. The repeal of sections 45D and E is consistent with that statement and, should actions be taken, the rights of companies that may feel aggrieved are at large and can be pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In briefing papers I received from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade before I went to New Zealand recently the department actually specifically stated that section 45D was the specific section of the Trade Practices Act which this government relies on as its bona fides when saying that it does not support the trans-Tasman shipping accord. If the government does not support it, what else is it doing to try to reduce the shipping costs across the Tasman? It is costing consumers on both sides of the Tasman too much at the moment. What is the government doing—apart from just saying that it does not support the trans-Tasman shipping accord—to get rid of the trans-Tasman shipping accord?

—This question should be directed to Senator Collins because it is within his portfolio of transport and communications that shipping issues arise. However, let me answer the question from the perspective of trade. The trans-Tasman accord is an agreement between two organisations on both sides of the Tasman.
—It is a restraint of trade. That is why it is your problem.

—If it has restrained trade, why are there no actions against the particular organisations concerned? The fact that an agreement exists does not mean to say it is operated, and it does not mean it restrains trade. There are, to the best of my knowledge, no legal actions being contemplated or taken against any of the unions. Therefore, one assumes that none of the companies concerned feel aggrieved enough to motivate themselves to do anything.
—Do you really believe that?
—Senator Campbell can joust after windmills, but in the real world of commercial activity no actions are being taken and no trade is being restrained, to the best of my knowledge.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. If the minister is so confident that the Uruguay Round of GATT will bring real benefits to Australians, despite evidence of diminished balance of trade following tariff reductions which have already taken place, especially in relation to our trade with China, why will he not immediately call for a full environmental and social impact assessment of this proposed agreement?

—We are talking here about apples and oranges. The question is a hard question to answer. It is, in fact, a very difficult question to answer because it involves so many notions which are, if I might say, with the greatest of respect, wrongly based or partly understood.

PARA.TAB: As I said in answer to an earlier question from Senator Jones, the successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round would mean to the global economy something like an income boost of $200 billion a year and to the Australian economy an income boost of $2.5 billion a year. It would be a direct line descendant from other multilateral negotiations—the Kennedy Round, the Tokyo Round—which have liberalised global trading rules and which have underpinned postwar economic growth in the world.

In fact, at the moment, with the global recession still languishing at the bottom of the index, there is a very good case to complete the round now and give the global economy the extra stimulus that a more liberalised trading regime would provide. That is a very worthwhile endeavour for Australia, a very big increase in the standard of living in this country, and a means of stimulating even greater growth rates in Australia and better standards of living for our citizens.

To confuse the rules under which trade should be conducted fairly, openly and transparently with what are the appropriate standards of environmental protection, the appropriate standards of labour regulation or the appropriate standards in any other field of social endeavour, is to try to apply to a set of rules which ensure the game is played fairly a set of subjective judgments about the quality of environmental conditions which those rules do not involve. To distort trade by using environmental arguments which result in one country applying to a sovereign other country its idea of what is a reasonable standard, not only violates, to some extent, the sovereign rights of the second country, but also, in the classic way in which this is used, gives force to greater protectionism and prevents freer trade. Thus, it circumvents the real rules of the GATT and what we are trying to achieve in the Uruguay Round, and undercuts the possibilities of greater economic stimulus.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in response to the resolution of the Senate yesterday requiring me to table certain documents relating to the drafting and validity of the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. I am advised by the Attorney-General that, apart from the advice received from Mr Dennis Rose QC, which was tabled earlier this week in the Senate, only one document is covered by the resolution.

PARA.TAB: That document, which I now table, is an opinion dated 12 August 1993 from Mr George Witynski of the Office of General Counsel in the Attorney-General's Department to Mr Keith Byles, the Senior Assistant Parliamentary Counsel of the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. That advice was in response to a request from the Office of Parliamentary Counsel as to whether an amendment to section 6 of the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986 to increase the rate of tax would be a law imposing taxation within the meaning of section 55 of the constitution.

In tabling this document, I want to make just a couple of points clearly for the record. Firstly, I am told that, apart from Mr Rose's opinion, there is no other advisory documentation in existence that was prepared in the context of the present bill. There also is no documentation in existence on other questions that the committee may wish to consider—for example, whether the various complex provisions of this bill could constitutionally be combined.

The fact that this is so is simply because, I am told, such advice was not considered necessary, the OPC regarding the applicable law is quite clear. If the amendment to section 6 of the Fringe Benefits Tax Act was not a bill imposing a tax—that is to say, the particular matter in respect of which it did seek advice—the question in its mind of the legality of combining the provisions simply did not arise. As I explained to the Senate at the time, Mr Rose's opinion was written in anticipation of the Senate committee and designed to bring conveniently together the various principles that have been accepted and routinely applied by the Attorney-General's Department and the OPC in the drafting of revenue legislation.

The second and final point I make is that the tabling of this advice should not be taken as a precedent binding the government henceforth to comply with requests to table documents of this or, indeed, any other kind. We will look at any such case on its own merits, having regard to the appropriate principles of confidentiality and public interest immunity. In this case, taking into account that there were no issues raised by this document other than the technical legal questions at the heart of the Senate committee's inquiry, I make no objection and table the document accordingly.

—But the fundamental proposition is what constitutes a law imposing taxation.
—That is the matter on which they did seek preliminary advice from Mr Witynski and that is what I tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that Australia has been extremely slow in addressing the problem of lead in petrol and the consequences in terms of the intellectual development of Australia's children. Some estimates suggest that some 44 per cent of Australian children may have impaired intelligence development as a direct consequence of the intake of lead, and principally the intake of lead which comes from the internal combustion engine. We have been very slow in adopting much lower levels of lead, despite the fact that evidence has been available for some 18 to 20 years linking levels of lead in children with impaired intellectual development.

PARA.TAB: The government has sought in this budget to introduce a price differential—again something for which the conservation movement has been pushing for a very long time—in an attempt to encourage those people who are capable of using unleaded fuel in their cars to make the shift. We would certainly support this move. However, we disagree totally with the government's intention simply to pass this price differential into general revenue. We believe that there is a marvellous opportunity here to more vigorously address this problem of lead in petrol.

There is a very adequate alternative to the use of lead in petrol, and that is to use ethanol as an octane enhancer. The addition of 10 per cent ethanol to unleaded petrol of an octane rating of 93 would raise the octane level to 96, and the 96 octane petrol could be used in the vast majority—probably all—of those pre-1986 cars which at the moment require the use of leaded petrol.

There are considerable advantages in going down this road. Ethanol is pre-eminently a renewable fuel. We have a large number of sources of fermentable material in this country which are currently going to waste. We already have an industry in New South Wales which is making quite large quantities of ethanol from wheat starch. We have an industry in Queensland which is also making ethanol from sugarcane and molasses. Alcohol from these sources is already contained in a very acceptable gasohol fuel in a limited number of service stations.

Australia also imports some $3.1 billion worth of petroleum each year and, as everybody in this chamber knows, our balance of trade is, to say the least, totally unsatisfactory. WINE TAX STUDY SHOWS DROP IN DEMAND AND EXPORTS
Premier Lynn Arnold today released an independent analysis of the impact of the Federal Government's decision to increase taxes on wine.

I refer to your letter of 20 May 1993 concerning the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Regulations, Statutory Rules 1993 No. 52. The letter advised that the Committee required further information relating to certain aspects of the regulations.

The Committee sought advice on whether the exercises of discretions provided in sub regulations 8(2), 8( 3) and 10(8) are subject to review on their merits by the AAT. The Committee was also concerned that sub regulations 10(9), 12(2) and 13(1) may have unfair effect.
In relation to sub regulations 8(2), 8(3) and 10(8) adequate review mechanisms are available under current law.
Sub regulation 8(2)
Sub regulation 8(2) provides that a superannuation guarantee statement must specify matters set out in the statement in sufficient detail to allow the proper consideration of the statement.

An employer is required to lodge a superannuation guarantee statement if the employer has a superannuation guarantee shortfall and, therefore, is liable to pay the superannuation guarantee charge. Subsection 33(2) of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 sets out the particulars to be included in that statement. Relevantly, subsection 33(3) specifies that the statement must be in a form approved by the Commissioner and lodged in accordance with the Regulations.

Subsection 33(2), by listing in detail the items that must be included in the statement, provides an objective standard for whether the statement is in sufficient detail to allow proper consideration of the statement. If the Commissioner concludes that a statement is not in sufficient detail to enable proper consideration and the statement is not amended, the employer would not have "lodged a statement" at all because either:

PARA.TAB: it would not be a statement; or

SPEECH.PARA: it would not be lodged in accordance with the Regulations.

Not having lodged a statement as required, the employer would then be assessed on an amount of additional tax (subsections 59(1) and 62(1)). This assessment carries with it all the normal rights of objection and appeal, either to the AAT or to the Federal Court, that attach to any other tax assessment (section 42). The employer would, as part of that process, be able to have the Commissioner's conclusion reviewed by either the AAT or the Federal Court.

The employer would also have a right to have the Federal Court review the Commissioner's decision not to approve the form in which the employer lodged the statement under section 5(1) of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. That is because the decision would be a decision of an administrative character made under the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992.
Sub regulation 8(3)

Sub regulation 8(3) deals with attachments to a superannuation guarantee statement and does not affect the primary requirements set out in subsections 33(2) and 33(3) relating to the particulars to be included in the statement. It sets out how an attachment to a superannuation guarantee statement must be prepared unless the Commissioner allows otherwise. In particular, it requires:
an endorsement with words stating that it is an attachment;

PARA.TAB: a signature by, or on behalf of, the employer;
a date; and
numbered pages.

SPEECH.PARA: A decision by the Commissioner to disallow departures from these rules would again be reviewable by the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.
The sub regulation is more detailed than, but otherwise essentially similar to, Regulation 27 of the Income Tax Regulations.
Sub regulation 10(8)

Sub regulation 10(8) provides that the Commissioner may allow a trustee a further period, beyond a 14 day period, to furnish the Commissioner a copy of a notice given to the trustee by an employee. The further period cannot extend beyond 10 years from the date the Commissioner gave notice to an employee regarding a shortfall component of the superannuation guarantee charge.
A decision under this sub regulation is also reviewable by the Federal Court under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.
Sub regulation 10(9)

Regulation 10 provides the mechanism for requesting the Commissioner to credit to an account for a person with a complying superannuation fund the shortfall component of the superannuation guarantee charge. This is done in three steps:
Step 1.The Commissioner notifies the employee of the shortfall component.
Step 2.The employee requests the trustee of a complying superannuation fund (CSF) to collect the shortfall component from the Commissioner.

Step 3.The trustee lodges with the Commissioner a copy of the request from the employee. The trustee must lodge this copy within 14 days of receipt from the employee or within a further period allowed by the Commissioner. This further period cannot be more than 10 years from the date of the notice given under step 1.

Sub regulation 10(9) provides that, if the request is not lodged with the Commissioner within 10 years, the employee's entitlement to the shortfall component is lost. The intention of this provision was that the employee should be encouraged to arrange for transfer of his or her entitlement to a complying superannuation fund within a reasonable period.

The ten year period was fixed so as to give employees and the CSF ample time to arrange for the crediting of the shortfall component. The time limit would, at the same time, facilitate cost effective administration of the superannuation guarantee charge by providing an appropriate time limit to the carry forward to unclaimed credits.
It would always be open to an employee to notify the Commissioner where a trustee unduly delays crediting his or her account with the shortfall component.
Sub regulation 12(2)

The standing Committee has pointed out that, under this sub regulation, a person representing an employee may be paid an allowance for attending before the Commissioner while a person representing an employer cannot be paid such allowance.

However, this sub regulation represents practice that has been in force for a long time. It is modelled on Regulation 174 of the Income Tax Regulations which allows for the payment of expenses other than to persons giving evidence in respect of their own income or assessment or the income or assessment of persons they represent.
It can be seen that the employer is the taxpayer and the employee would merely be a witness, so the parallel is exact.
Sub regulation 13(1)

The Standing Committee expressed concern that an employee may be disadvantaged if the employer did not notify the Commissioner of a change of address of the employee. In this case, the old address is treated as the postal address.

Under the superannuation guarantee scheme the Commissioner's initial contact is with the employer. The employer provides the particulars relating to the employee. As indicated earlier, the Commissioner will also endeavour to obtain the correct address of the employee from information available to the Commissioner.

The sub regulation is essential for administration purposes. The principle embodied in the sub regulation has for long been embodied in taxation legislation. An example is the present Regulation 38 of the Income Tax Regulations.
GARY JOHNS

SPEECH.PARA: In `Building On Strength' the government announced as part of its advancement towards a fairer Australia that it would improve the position of low income retirees by easing the pensions assets test and by introducing a seniors health card.

Soon after, the government fulfilled the first part of this commitment by introducing legislation to ease the pensions assets test from 20 September 1993. This bill will meet the second part of that commitment by introducing a seniors health card from 1 July 1994 that will give certain older low income non-pensioner retirees access to concessional pharmaceutical benefits and to hearing aid concessions. It is estimated that this initiative will assist 200,000 people.

The payment of pharmaceutical allowance was introduced in November 1990 to offset the introduction of a charge for pharmaceutical benefits for persons who had previously received prescriptions free under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. At that time, the government decided that as an interim measure, certain persons were to be eligible for payment of advances of that allowance.

The government has now decided that the period in which advances of payment of pharmaceutical allowance will be payable should be further extended until 31 December 1994. This bill gives effect to that decision.

Since coming to office in 1983, much has been achieved in assisting Australian families. For example, the government introduced the Family Allowance Supplement and later integrated family payments for children so as to reduce poverty traps, improve work incentives for low income families, increase the take-up rate of the family payment for low income families with children and help families to budget better. The government remains committed to protecting and enhancing the interests of families. However, it is important that this be achieved equitably and targeted towards those people who are most in need.
The government is concerned that the use of taxable income alone might not be a reliable basis upon which to determine entitlement to certain social security payments.

For example, some people receive benefits from their employer such as a car or rent-free housing but do not pay any tax on them because the definition of `taxable income' in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 does not include the value of such benefits. Instead, the employer is subject to fringe benefits tax.

To qualify for a family payment under the Social Security Act 1991, a person must satisfy an income test. Similarly, a person aged under 18 who applies for a job search allowance or a sickness allowance is subject to a parental income test. At present, both of these income tests are based on `taxable income' that is defined to mean the same as in the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. As a result, these income tests do not take account of employer provided fringe benefits. This means that some people who have a high income in real terms, can still pass the income tests. This gives an unfair advantage to those people who receive income in the form of fringe benefits rather than as wages.

Accordingly, the government has decided to amend the Social Security Act 1991 from 1 January 1994 to make sure that the income tests for family payment and the parental income test for job search allowance and sickness allowance claimants aged under 18 take account of certain employer fringe benefits. The benefits that will be assessable are employer provided motor vehicles, housing, loans, school fees and private health insurance. The value of the benefits of a person and the person's partner, or parent as the case may be, will be added together and anything in excess of $1,000 will be taken into account. If the combined total is less than that amount it will be ignored.

Another example of where inequity can arise is where despite having similar levels of income, one family can be advantaged over another merely because the source of some or all of their income is overseas. The foreign income might not form part of their `taxable income' upon which entitlement to family payment is based. This can occur, for instance, because one parent works overseas and is not resident in Australia for the purposes of Australian taxation legislation.

To that end, the Social Security Act 1991 is to be amended with effect from 1 January 1994 to allow certain foreign income to be taken into account when assessing a person's entitlement to family payment. This measure will not affect families receiving social security pensions or benefits or service pensions as they are exempt from the family payment income test.

Many social security pensioners receive foreign income. That income must be converted to Australian dollars to calculate the rate of Australian pension payable. Currently, unless exceptional circumstances prevail, the foreign currency provisions in the Social Security Act 1991 only enable the exchange rates used for this purpose to be changed four times a year. However, due to the needs-based nature of Australia's social security system, we must be more flexible.

The bill will amend the foreign currency conversion provisions in the act so that they will be more responsive to frequent or sudden movements in exchange rates. A new exchange rate for each nominated currency will be set every pension payday, based on the market exchange rate available at the Commonwealth Bank of Australia on the previous payday. If there is no such rate for that payday, for example, because of a national public holiday, the rate used will be the market exchange rate that applied on the last working day immediately before that payday.
I commend the bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly, recognising that the Senate estimates committees are about to sit. I wish to thank the Senate for the support it has just given to the motion I moved in relation to an inquiry into whilsteblowing in this country. When I had the responsibility of the shadow portfolio of defence science and personnel, over the years a number of people came to me who—in the national interest, as they saw it—had tried to report matters of maladministration or even corruption which needed attention. As a result of reporting these matters their careers suffered and eventually, in some cases, their health suffered. I was also made aware of somebody from the department of administrative services who was exposed to fraudulent contracting in relation to defence projects. That man gave information on what he had found and, at least partly as a result of that, prosecutions followed.

PARA.TAB: The only trouble is that while these people have been doing their duty in the national interest, as they see it, organisations for which they have worked have felt threatened and the procedures currently in place—like the merit review procedures—do not appear to have given sufficient protection to people from harassment, intimidation or even sacking. We realise that this is a matter which is not easy to prove, but so also is sexual harassment in the workplace. This country still believes that it is appropriate to have legislation on the books so that, where such harassment can be proved, action can be taken to protect the individuals concerned. I would argue that a similar situation should prevail in the case of whistleblowers.

The whistleblowers who have come to my attention have not gone public. There is a misapprehension abroad that whistleblowers are somehow disloyal to the organisation for which they work because they go public. Frequently, they do not go public; they go to a very senior officer and then the organisation punishes them accordingly.

I have had this concern for a long time. What finally moved me to take action was not a case in the public sector but a case in the private sector, in my home state of Tasmania. I will briefly set out what the problem is there. An article written by Terry McCrann in today's Herald-Sun states:

Back in 1990 Alwyn Johnson, who was one of the most senior executives in Tasmania's biggest bank—the state-government owned Tasmania Bank—raised the alarm on serious undisclosed financial problems within the bank.

He did so by writing two confidential letters to the then Tasmanian premier Michael Field. This led to the premier calling in the external auditors to examine the bank's position and the subsequent departure of the bank's two top executives.

The bad loan problems were `solved' in the old-fashioned way by merging Tasmania Bank with the state's other major local bank to form the now-named Trust Bank—in the process, removing the state's government ownership, as also happened with the State Bank of Victoria.

Rather than being rewarded for preventing the problems worsening to the point which could have threatened the viability of the bank, Mr Johnson was frozen out of the new executive structure at the merged bank, and was summarily and effectively dismissed in mid-1991.
That happened some time after he had disclosed his identity as the whistle-blower to both the new chief executive of Trust Bank and the Reserve Bank governor Bernie Fraser.

Until that point, his identity had not been revealed. This is very important, for at no stage until his dismissal had Mr Johnson gone public. He had only sought to very privately alert the bank's owner—the state government—to the festering sore.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that sums up why we need to protect people who act in the public interest. If people had acted in that way in other banks in Australia, we might have avoided some of the disasters that have been occasioned to this nation. The Commonwealth does have the responsibility to regulate banking and it has a regulatory body in the form of the Reserve Bank. It also has regulatory bodies in terms of the corporations of Australia and the air safety of Australia. People working in corporations or in the aviation industry could well have information which is in the national interest, but they hesitate to go to, say, the regulatory authority for fear of retribution.

PARA.TAB: A number of public committees have briefly touched on the issue of whistleblowing. The most recent was a Senate committee in December 1991 which reviewed the Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman. That committee said that `there was an increase of the phenomenon of individuals drawing attention to what they see as misbehaviour by the organisations which employ them—a practice often called whistleblowing. In some cases such behaviour represents courage and a commitment to high ethical standards far beyond the normal. In other cases it involves stubborn persistence in error to an extent that is destructive of the complainant and damaging to the organisation subject to complaint'. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on the adjournment to briefly discuss a matter that was raised in question time today. I refer to the visit, as one might call it, of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) to the ACTU congress. The answer to my question given by Senator McMullan, in his capacity as minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, highlighted very distinctly the division between the Labor Party and its accord partners, the trade union movement.

PARA.TAB: I wish briefly to highlight the government's changing position over the past two or three months on the subject of industrial relations. I do that against the background of what I believe must be an unprecedented occurrence today, namely, that the Minister for Industrial Relations was booed and hissed by his accord partners at the ACTU congress. That is surely a unique event in the history of the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Senator Crane.
—Well, it is not a very frequent occurrence. I certainly have not heard of its happening before, and the same position applies to the attack by Mr Kelty on Mr Brereton today.

PARA.TAB: I want to show how out of control this government is on this issue when it is changing position. In April the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) addressed the Institute of Directors in Australia, and said:

SPEECH.PARA: We need to find a way of extending the coverage of workplace agreements from being add-ons to awards, as they sometimes are, to being full substitutes for awards.

Approximately one month ago the Minister for Industrial Relations brought down a statement in which he indicated that it was his intention to extend enterprise bargaining in total freedom to non-union workplaces. I emphasise—in total freedom to non-union workplaces. Only two days ago the Prime Minister changed his position. He said:
We are close to an agreement with the ACTU on a package of labour reforms based on a proposal by the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Kelty.

This highlights the fact that the position adopted by Mr Brereton just over a month ago has been totally eroded and a position has been put in place which has been controlled by the Prime Minister and Mr Kelty; it is out of Mr Brereton's hands. It is worth noting two things about what took place yesterday. Today's Australian Financial Review reports:

PARA.TAB: Mr Brereton's office said yesterday he remained committed to opening up enterprise bargaining in the non-unionised work force—a significant step down from his earlier plan to allow—

SPEECH.PARA: I underline the word `allow'—
non-union workers to actually strike enterprise agreements.
So even Mr Brereton has changed his position significantly. Also yesterday, as reported by the Australian Financial Review:

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Mr Tickner, reflected the anger in Labor's federal Caucus about the industrial reforms in a speech to the congress . . .

SPEECH.PARA: So not only is Mr Brereton out of step with the trade union movement; he is also out of step with the people in his own caucus. The article reports Mr Tickner as saying:
. . . government policies should take union views into account.

Obviously Senator McMullan is having some problem with this proposition. When I asked today whether the government was going to cave in to the position being put by the union movement, as enunciated by the minister for Aboriginal affairs, Mr Tickner, at the ACTU conference yesterday, he could not have given a much shorter or explicit answer. He said: `No'. There is an enormous amount of contradiction and conflict between the positions of the various ministers within the government, the position of Mr Kelty and, also, the position of Mr Ferguson as President of the ACTU, as to where industrial relations is heading.

PARA.TAB: It is also worth noting that in his speech today Mr Brereton spelt out some intentions which—and he was booed and hissed at the ACTU Congress—we on this side of the chamber will certainly be opposing as we believe they represent an incredibly backward step in industrial relations in this country—the right to free trade, the right to free enterprise, the rights of the individual, and a measure whereby people by de facto means will be forced into compulsory unionism.

The first point I want to make on this issue is that, quite clearly, the right to strike will be introduced into the legislation. The second point, which was also alluded to in an answer to a different question by Senator Cook here today, concerns the abolition of sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act. Once again, I believe that this is a backward step. It is certainly a step which—and we have been taking evidence in an inquiry into sections 45D and 45E—no employer organisation in this country supports. The third point I want to make concerns the unionisation of non-union workplaces by default. Of course, in effect this is all about compulsory unionism. This package, if implemented, will mean that Australia will be taking an enormous step backwards.

The other point that I wish to highlight is that Mr Brereton's speech remains absolutely and totally silent with regard to how or by what means we might see the development of enterprise bargaining in non-union workplaces. That is notable for its absence. It is highlighted by what Mr Kelty had to say today. I quote from AAP as follows:
ACTU Secretary Bill Kelty followed Mr Brereton's speech with a blunt statement on union opposition to the certification of non-union enterprise deals.

SPEECH.PARA: We know what the answer to that will be, because the government has been told by its masters.

PARA.TAB: I would like to make a couple of brief comments with regard to sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. They have been consistently misrepresented by so many groups in this country in terms of what they can and cannot do. The first point is that sections 45D and 45E give quick, speedy and relatively inexpensive relief through an injunction to interference in people's rights to go about their business and to trade in a nonrestrictive manner.

The next point, which has been consistently misrepresented, is that the legislation can be used against people who take action in the workplace about their legitimate concerns—concerns about their pay, concerns about their safety and concerns about the conditions under which they work. In relation to people protecting themselves in the workplace, subsection 45D(3) of the Trade Practices Act precisely and clearly spells out that that is not the case. This has also been upheld in the courts. The most notable case was the MATFA v. AMIEU case in 1990 in Victoria which related to certain aspects of the accord mark 6. I will not go into the detail of that case, other than to put it on the public record that, when individuals in the workplace either singularly or collectively were concerned about those particular aspects, legitimate protection was given to them under sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act.

I also want to touch on the much misrepresented situation with regard to civil liberties. This was spelt out quite clearly in the J-Corp case in Western Australia. In this particular case, interference by the BLF on J-Corp occurred by virtue of a picket line. But, even though damage occurred to J-Corp, because the principal target was the previous state Labor government in Western Australia and Homeswest, the court decided not to order an injunction against that action because the prime target was not the business that was being interfered with. So the civil liberties of the BLF in protesting against the Western Australian government were upheld. That was a very important case because it put an end to the lie which has been espoused around the place that sections 45D and 45E are used to prevent people from protesting in a civil form.

This whole gambit of removing sections 45D and 45E from the Trade Practices Act will mean that once again Australian businesses, trade, shipping and transport industries—the lot—will be exposed to the types of things that occurred before 1977 without any proper recourse to the law.

It is pointless for people to stand in this place and say, as we heard today, that there are common law remedies which are effective. There are common law remedies, it is true. But one can wait up to two or three years before it goes before the court. One has to deal with all the jurisdictions of the supreme courts around this country. One gets inconsistencies between judgments from supreme courts and the Federal Court. At the end of the day, the rights of people to trade in a fair and proper manner without interference is the issue. That is what sections 45D and 45E are all about.

I want to highlight two points with regard to the proposal to put it under industrial law. Firstly, it will be restricted to those who are covered by federal awards. Secondly, because of the proposals outlined in Mr Brereton's speech, there will be a period in which the arbitration commission will have to deal with the matter. Of course, we know what happens then. Businesses cannot be held up for days, weeks and months waiting for an outcome in these particular circumstances because they will go broke. That is what was happening prior to 1977. That is why sections 45D and 45E were put into the Trade Practices Act—to give immediate injunctive relief from action while the matter was sorted out.

Putting it under industrial law would be an enormous backward step for this country at this time, particularly when we have a compulsory arbitration system which operates here. I note that in Mr Brereton's speech he expressed no intention of doing away with compulsory arbitration.

I leave my comments there. Once again, I highlight the fact that Mr Brereton was hissed and booed today; the conflict that obviously arose from the answer given by Senator McMullan to my question today in relation to the position of Mr Tickner yesterday; and the changing position of the Prime Minister and Mr Brereton. I emphasise that the Labor Party is in total disarray—probably in more disarray over this than with its budget—as far as a proper, fair and equitable industrial relations policy is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) In this age of automatic electronic transfer and verification of funds, how do banks explain the fact that clearance of cheques takes virtually the same period as before electronic transfer was introduced.
(2) What happens to such funds between the time they are deposited and made available to the client.
(3) If the funds are invested by the banks during this period what happens to the interest accrued on the investments.
(4) Have complaints on this anomaly in the banking system been referred to, or been the subject of investigation by, the Banking Ombudsman.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Electronic transfer and verification technology to date has not displaced the physical transfer of cheques. The time banks allow for cheque clearance relates not to the time required to transmit the details of a transaction from the bank where it is deposited (collecting bank) to the bank on which it was drawn (drawee bank), which is nowadays quite short, but to the time needed to cover the possible two-way journey of the physical cheque through the system.

The cheque-clearing cycle involves time for the cheque to be sorted and sent to the drawee bank; time for that bank to decide whether to honour the cheque; and if the cheque is not to be honoured, time to return it through the system. If a collecting bank pays away on a cheque before it is verified and cleared by the drawee bank it runs the risk of loss if the cheque is dishonoured, for reasons including insufficient funds or fraud.

(2,3) The proceeds from deposits of cheques awaiting final clearance are usually at the disposal of the collecting bank which is able to invest them. Depending on the nature of the account into which cheques are deposited, customers are either paid interest on these proceeds from the day of deposit or they are applied to reducing overdrafts. In some countries the customer would not get the benefit of the interest paid (or saved) until the funds were deemed to be clear some days after the day of deposit.

(4) I understand that the Banking Ombudsman has received inquiries relating to cheque clearance times and the position of uncleared funds. The majority of inquirers apparently accept the situation when told that, although uncleared, funds attract interest from the time of lodgement in accounts.

The only instances where disputes involving cheque clearance times have been formally investigated by the Banking Ombudsman's office are where it is alleged that bank staff have provided incorrect or misleading information on the clearing process, and that this has caused the customer loss or disadvantage.

A set of principles to govern the charging of fees throughout the HACC Program has been agreed by Commonwealth and State HACC Officials. A Commonwealth/State working group is now in the process of translating these principles into a national fees policy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Family Services, upon notice on 21 July 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Statutory Rules Nos 140 and 141 of 1993:
(1) Who was consulted in relation to the increases and extension of fees set out in the regulations.
(2) On what basis were the increases and extension of fees determined.
(3) What improvement in performance can be expected from the Therapeutic Goods Administration as a consequence of the increases and extension of fees.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) has consulted with four peak industry organisations. The organisations are:

TAB.TAB: Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association Inc
Medical Industries Association of Australia Inc
Nutritional Foods Association of Australia Inc
The Proprietary Medicines Association of Australia Inc.

PARA.TAB: The need to increase the fees and charges set out in the regulations was discussed with the organisations individually and also within the Industry/Government Consultative Committee (IGCC) which is a committee involving the four peak organisations together with representation from TGA, the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development, and the Department of Finance.

(2) The fees and charges levied by TGA were introduced in 1991 following the passage of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. Fees and charges were established through consultation with the IGCC against estimates of the volume of work likely to be undertaken. In the first full year of operation (1991-92) TGA raised $9.4M in revenue compared to a target of $17M to meet 50% cost-recovery. The first discussions with industry on the need to increase fees and charges took place in May 1992. The need to increase fees and charges was widely publicised in the "TGA News", a newsletter sent to all sponsors of pharmaceutical goods in Australia.

Following detailed discussions which involved the peak organisations, the Department of Finance, the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development, and the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet it was decided to phase in an increase in fees and charges over four years commencing on 1 July 1993. Annual increases will take place until and including the 1996-97 financial year when it is estimated that the 50% cost-recovery target will be achieved.

(3) The present increase in fees and charges is not directly related to performance but is a requirement to meet the government policy that TGA generate revenue to meet 50% of its budget. The operating budget of TGA has not been increased in any real terms, the increase in fees and charges is required to meet the government policy on revenue generation.

The performance of TGA is monitored through the IGCC and through the publication of quarterly performance reports. The performance indicators for TGA were determined by the IGCC and are used as management tools by TGA.

TGA has improved its performance since the implementation of the Baume Report and through adopting new strategies throughout the Branches in TGA involved with the approvals of drugs and medical devices.

There is a financial incentive for the approval of prescription medicines to be completed by the TGA within the timelines proposed by Baume and now specified in Regulations. For Category 1 and 2 applications, 75% of the evaluation fee is payable when the application is accepted for evaluation and the remaining 25% is payable only if the evaluation and decision is completed within the allotted time period.
The sponsor may not proceed to market until registration is approved and the drug entered on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods.
